title: 106_s2588
content: The "Ute-Moab Land Restoration Act" is cited as the short title. Section 3405 of the Strom Thurmond National Defense Authorization Act is amended to transfer Oil Shale Reserve Numbered 2. In this section, key definitions are provided including "map," "Moab site," "NOSR-2," and "Tribe." The Moab site is specifically identified as the uranium milling site near Moab, Utah. The conveyance of Oil Shale Reserve Numbered 2 is also mentioned in the context of the Ute-Moab Land Restoration Act. The United States conveys Federal land within NOSR-2 to the Tribe in fee simple, excluding certain reservations like a 9 percent royalty interest in minerals. The United States conveys Federal land within NOSR-2 to the Tribe in fee simple, excluding certain reservations like a 9 percent royalty interest in minerals. The conveyed land includes portions of the Green River bed, land to the west of the river, and a scenic easement on the east side. Upon completion of the conveyance, the United States relinquishes all management authority over the conveyed land. The United States conveys Federal land within NOSR-2 to the Tribe in fee simple, excluding certain reservations like a 9 percent royalty interest in minerals. The conveyed land includes portions of the Green River bed, land to the west of the river, and a scenic easement on the east side. The land conveyed to the Tribe shall not revert to the United States for management in trust status. The reservation of the easement shall not affect the Tribe's right to access the Green River through the road within the easement. All withdrawals in effect on NOSR-2 are revoked. The Secretary shall administer the reserved land and interests in land. The Secretary shall submit a land use plan for the management of the conveyed land and interests in land to Congress within 3 years of enactment. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose. A royalty interest reserved from conveyance in subsection (b)(2)(A) must be paid by the Tribe. The Tribe is not required to pay for development, production, marketing, and operating expenses. The United States is responsible for paying gross production taxes, pipeline taxes, and allocation taxes. The Tribe must submit an annual report on resource development activities. A financial audit is required every 5 years. The Tribe must obtain an audit of all resource development activities every 5 years, as per chapter 75 of title 31, United States Code. The results of each audit must be included in the next annual report. The Tribe is responsible for managing land adjacent to the Green River to maintain its protected status. The Tribe must maintain the protected status of the land and follow the government-to-government agreement. Any ordinance adopted should not restrict non-tribal land use without approval from the Tribe and the Secretary. Additionally, plant species are addressed in the legislation. The Tribe must protect endangered plant species on NOSR-2 land under tribal jurisdiction as per a government-to-government agreement with the Secretary. Additionally, the Tribe is responsible for managing and protecting horses. The Tribe is responsible for managing, protecting, and asserting control over horses not owned by the Tribe on NOSR-2 land. This must be done in accordance with Federal law and a government-to-government agreement with the Secretary. Additionally, the Secretary of Energy must take remedial action at the Moab site within a year. The Secretary of Energy must prepare a plan for remedial action at the Moab site within a year, in accordance with the Uranium Mill Tailings Radiation Control Act. Expenditures for the action are limited to appropriated funds and other available amounts. Royalties received must be retained by the Secretary. The Secretary of Energy must retain royalties received for remedial action at the Moab site without further appropriation. Excess amounts will be deposited in the Treasury, and necessary funds are authorized for the action. The Secretary will continue remediation activities at the Moab site using available funds until additional funds are allocated. The trustee appointed by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission will also carry out remediation activities at the site. If the Moab site is sold, specific provisions will apply. If the Moab site is sold after the completion of remedial action, the seller must pay the Secretary of Energy the portion of the sale price attributed to the enhanced value of the site. The enhanced value is determined as the difference between the fair market value before and after the remedial action. The Moab site's fair market value will be determined based on information available on the date of enactment and appraised after completion of the remedial action. SEC. 3. URANIUM MILL TAILINGS. The Moab uranium milling site in Utah is designated as a processing site under the Uranium Mill Tailings Radiation Control Act of 1978. This designation applies to the site in the same manner as other processing sites under the Act. The Moab site in Utah is designated for processing under the Uranium Mill Tailings Radiation Control Act of 1978. The Secretary will conduct remediation at the site in a safe and environmentally sound manner, including groundwater restoration and removal to another designated site. The Secretary will remove residual radioactive material and contaminated material from the Moab Site in Utah for permanent disposition and stabilization at a designated site in the state. Section 3406 of the Strom Thurmond National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1999 is amended to exclude the transfer of Oil Shale Reserve Numbered 2 under section 3405.
